name: The Wakan
description: The spiritual beings of the Lakota (Western Sioux), anchored to Mato Tipila — Bear Lodge — the great igneous monolith in northeastern Wyoming that rises 1,267 feet above the Belle Fourche River. In the Lakota telling, seven sisters fleeing a giant bear climbed onto a low rock and prayed; the rock surged skyward, and the bear scored its sides with massive claw marks as it tried to reach them, carving the columnar grooves visible today. The sisters rose beyond its reach and became the Pleiades. Lakota spirituality is not a pantheon of discrete gods ruling separate departments but a web of relationships held together by one foundational principle: Mitakuye Oyasin — all are related. The sacred powers are called Wakan, and they move through everything that exists.

deities.name: Wakan Tanka
deities.title: The Great Mystery
deities.description: Wakan Tanka is not a being in the Western theological sense — not a creator who stands outside creation and governs it, not a personality with preferences and moods. Wakan Tanka is the totality of the sacred, the sum of all wakan powers and the mystery that exceeds that sum. James R. Walker, working with Lakota holy men including Finger, Sword, and Thomas Tyon at Pine Ridge between 1896 and 1914, documented the concept with care: Wakan Tanka encompasses sixteen aspects — four Superior, four Associate, four Subordinate, and four Soul-like powers — but the whole is greater than the parts. The phrase is better translated as 'the Great Mystery' or 'the Great Incomprehensible' than 'the Great Spirit,' which too easily collapses into a monotheistic frame the Lakota did not hold. Black Elk, speaking to John Neihardt in 1931, described wakan as the sacred quality that pervades all things — the rock, the grass, the thunder, the human being. Everything participates in Wakan Tanka because everything is related. This is a theology built on mystery itself rather than certainty, which carries a psychological implication worth sitting with: if the foundation of your spiritual life is an acknowledgment that the ultimate nature of things exceeds comprehension, then humility is not a virtue you cultivate but the ground you stand on. The Sacred Pipe brought by White Buffalo Calf Woman is the instrument through which humans communicate with Wakan Tanka, the smoke carrying prayers upward, the bowl representing the earth, the stem representing all that grows. At Mato Tipila, where the rock itself surged upward from the earth in response to prayer, Wakan Tanka is the force that answered.
colors: all colors — each direction carries its own
animals: all living beings participate in Wakan Tanka

deities.name: Wi
deities.title: The Sun
deities.description: Wi is the chief of the Superior Wakan Beings, the Sun, the great arbiter whose light makes all things visible and whose judgment is therefore inescapable. In Walker's interviews, the Lakota holy man Sword explained that Wi presides over the four great virtues — bravery, fortitude, generosity, and wisdom — and that the Sun Dance, the most sacred of the seven rites brought by White Buffalo Calf Woman, is performed in his honor. The Sun Dance (Wiwanyag Wachipi, 'gazing at the sun') is not worship in the passive sense; it is an ordeal. Dancers pierce their chest or back with skewers attached by thongs to the sacred cottonwood tree at the center of the dance circle and pull against the tethers while gazing at the sun, sometimes for days, until the flesh tears free. The suffering is voluntary and offered for the people — the dancer sacrifices not animals or enemies but his own body, making the theology of reciprocity radically personal. Wi's light exposes everything, which is why deceit is an offense against the Sun specifically. His wife is Hanwi, the Moon, who was tricked by the trickster Iktomi into sitting in Wi's place at a feast, and Wi banished her to the night sky in shame — she covers her face, which is why the moon waxes and wanes. The direction of the East belongs to Wi, and the color red is his. At Mato Tipila, the Sun's first light strikes the tower's summit and slides down the columnar grooves each morning, illuminating the claw marks of the great bear that could not reach the sisters who became stars.

deities.name: Skan
deities.title: The Sky / Motion
deities.description: Skan is the sky itself and, more precisely, the force of motion that animates the sky — the power that moves the sun, the moon, the stars, the clouds, and the wind across the vault of the heavens. Walker's informants described Skan as the judge of all the gods, the arbiter of disputes among the Superior Wakan Beings, the one whose decisions cannot be appealed. When Wi punished Hanwi for her transgression, it was Skan who decreed the terms. Skan is also the source of the spirit, the nagi, that inhabits every living being; he breathes the spirit into existence and receives it back at death. This makes Skan the closest the Lakota system comes to a concept of cosmic law — not a lawgiver in the sense of commandments etched in stone, but the principle of motion itself, the fact that the universe does not stand still, that everything circles, migrates, transforms, and returns. The psychological resonance is in the identification of spirit with motion: to be alive is to be in motion, and when motion stops, the spirit departs. Depression, in this framework, would be understood as a failure of Skan's breath — a stilling of what should move. The blue of the sky is Skan's color. Skan has no single animal form because his domain is movement itself — he is present wherever anything changes position. At Mato Tipila, Skan is the sky that the tower pierces, the vast dome above the monolith that the seven sisters passed through on their way to becoming the Pleiades, the medium through which the bear's roar echoed and faded into silence.

deities.name: Inyan
deities.title: The Rock / First Being
deities.description: Inyan is the Rock, and in the Lakota creation account recorded by Walker, Inyan is the first being — the original existence before anything else. In the beginning there was only Inyan, and Inyan was soft and shapeless and all-powerful, but he was alone, and he desired to exercise his power. So he spread himself out to create the earth, and in doing so he opened his veins, and his blood, which was blue, flowed out of him and became the waters and the sky (Skan). The effort of creation drained him; he shrank, hardened, and became the stone that underlies all things. This is a creation myth of extraordinary psychological depth: the first being creates the world through self-sacrifice, and the act of creation permanently diminishes the creator. Power is not free. Every act of making costs something irreplaceable. Inyan did not create from surplus but from his own substance, and he can never be what he was before. The blue of his blood became the blue of both water and sky, which is why Lakota ceremony uses the colors together. His hardened body is every rock, every cliff, every mountain. Mato Tipila — Bear Lodge — is Inyan made spectacularly visible: a mass of phonolite porphyry that solidified from magma approximately 50 million years ago, exposed by erosion, standing as the literal body of the first being who gave everything to make the world. When Lakota people regard the tower as sacred, they are recognizing that rock is not dead matter but the oldest ancestor, the one who was here first and who remains after everything else has moved on.

deities.name: Maka
deities.title: The Earth
deities.description: Maka is the Earth — not the planet as viewed from space but the living ground, the surface and depth of the land that holds everything. In the Walker accounts, Maka was created from Inyan's body when he spread himself out, and she was originally the same substance as Inyan, but distinguished from him by becoming the ground rather than remaining the rock beneath it. She complained to Skan about her nakedness and cold, and Skan decreed that Wi should warm her, which established the relationship between the sun and the earth. Maka is the mother in the most literal, material sense: everything that grows comes from her body, every root pushes through her flesh, every creature walks on her skin. She is not sentimental about this. The Lakota relationship to the land was not the romantic 'nature worship' that European observers projected onto it but a kinship relationship with specific obligations — you do not take from a relative without reciprocity. The concept of owning Maka would be as incoherent as owning your mother. Her color is green, the color of growing things, and her presence is felt wherever earth is exposed and unbuilt upon. The Black Hills — Paha Sapa — are called the heart of everything that is, and Mato Tipila stands at their northwestern edge as a sentinel. The columnar basalt of the tower rose through Maka's body; the sedimentary layers that once covered it eroded away over millions of years, revealing the hard igneous core. Maka bore this intrusion, held it, and in time let it stand exposed. The landscape around Bear Lodge is her expression: grassland, ponderosa pine forest, the Belle Fourche River curving past the tower's base, the red soil of the Wyoming hills.

deities.name: Tate
deities.title: The Wind
deities.description: Tate is the Wind, companion to Skan and the force that connects all four directions. In the Walker narratives, Tate is the father of the Four Winds — the sons who govern the cardinal directions and who compete among themselves for precedence, establishing the seasonal cycle through their rivalry. Yata, the North Wind, brings cold and hardship. Okaga, the South Wind, brings warmth and growth. Yanpa, the East Wind, carries the dawn. Waziyata, the West Wind, brings rain and thunder. Tate's lodge stands at the center of the world, and his sons go out from it and return to it, each dominant in his season. The concept is not merely meteorological; it encodes a theory of change. The Lakota four directions are not points on a compass but qualities of experience — the North teaches endurance, the South teaches generosity, the East teaches illumination, the West teaches introspection. Tate, as the wind that moves between all four, is the medium of transition itself. You cannot have the South without the North, the dawn without the evening. He is the breath that moves through the Sacred Pipe during ceremony, carrying prayers from the visible world to the wakan powers. At Mato Tipila, wind is constant and significant — the tower rises into exposed air, and the gusts that pour across the Wyoming grasslands and funnel around the monolith's columnar walls make an audible sound, a low tone that shifts with speed and direction. Prairie peoples live in wind the way coastal peoples live in salt air. Tate is not background; he is the atmosphere you think in.
colors: varies by the directional son — white, red, yellow, black

deities.name: Wakinyan
deities.title: The Thunderbird
deities.description: Wakinyan, the Thunderbird, is the great winged being whose beating wings create thunder and whose glancing eyes produce lightning. He nests on the highest peak in the Black Hills — Harney Peak (now Black Elk Peak) — and guards the western gate of the world. In Black Elk's account to Neihardt, the Thunderbird is one of the most vivid and fearsome of all wakan beings, not a metaphor for storms but the being that is the storm. When Wakinyan flies, the sky darkens; his wingbeats roll across the plains as thunder; when he blinks, lightning flashes. He is the enemy of Unk and of Iya, the water monster and the storm monster, and his battles with them are visible in the collision of weather fronts across the Great Plains — a landscape where you can see storms approaching from fifty miles away and watch the full arc of a thunderhead's life from birth to dissolution. Wakinyan is deeply connected to the heyoka, the sacred clowns of Lakota society. Anyone struck by lightning or who dreams of the Thunderbird is called to become a heyoka — to do everything backward, to say the opposite of what they mean, to ride facing the horse's tail, to shiver in summer and sweat in winter. The heyoka is not a fool but a mirror: by inverting everything, the heyoka reveals the arbitrariness of convention and forces the community to see its assumptions. This is the Thunderbird's psychological function — not comfort but disruption, not confirmation but the shattering insight that arrives uninvited. At Mato Tipila, summer thunderstorms build rapidly over the tower, and lightning has struck the summit many times. The Thunderbird's domain is the sky above the monolith where the seven sisters ascended, the storm country of the northern Plains.
animals: eagle (related — but Wakinyan is his own form)

deities.name: Whope
deities.title: The White Buffalo Calf Woman
deities.description: Whope — also known as Ptesan Wi, White Buffalo Calf Woman — is the sacred figure who brought the chanunpa, the Sacred Pipe, to the Lakota people, along with the seven sacred rites that organize their spiritual life. The story, told by Black Elk to Joseph Epes Brown in The Sacred Pipe, is one of the great sacred encounters in any tradition: two young men were hunting when a beautiful woman appeared, walking toward them out of the mist. One man looked at her with desire; the other recognized something wakan. When the lustful man reached for her, a cloud enveloped them both, and when it cleared only his bones remained, covered with snakes. The woman instructed the other to return to camp and prepare a lodge. She arrived carrying the Sacred Pipe and taught the people its meaning — the bowl of red catlinite represents the earth and all four-legged creatures, the wooden stem represents all that grows from the earth, the twelve eagle feathers hanging from the stem represent the winged peoples, and when the pipe is joined and smoked, all creation is connected and prayers rise with the smoke to Wakan Tanka. She taught them the seven sacred rites: the Sweat Lodge, the Vision Quest, the Sun Dance, the Making of Relatives, the Keeping of the Soul, the Girl's Coming of Age, and the Throwing of the Ball. Then she walked away, and as the people watched, she rolled on the ground and became a black buffalo, then a brown buffalo, then a red buffalo, and finally a white buffalo calf before disappearing over the hill. The birth of a white buffalo calf is still regarded as a sacred event among the Lakota. Whope's teachings are not mythology in the past tense; they are the living foundation of Lakota ceremonial life practiced today. At Mato Tipila, prayer bundles and offerings left at the tower's base are expressions of the relationship she established — the pipe as the bridge between the human and the sacred.

deities.name: Unk
deities.title: Goddess of Water and Passion
deities.description: Unk is the goddess of water, passion, and the dangerous depths — the being who governs the turbulent, unpredictable powers that lie beneath surfaces. In the Walker narratives, Unk is associated with Iya, the storm monster, and with the Unktehi, the great water spirits that inhabit lakes and rivers and whose conflicts with the Thunderbird produce the violent weather of the Great Plains. She represents desire, jealousy, and the emotional undertow that pulls people away from the balanced path. But reducing Unk to a cautionary figure misses the relational logic of Lakota theology: she exists because the system requires her. Without the pull of passion, without the undertow of deep feeling, there is no tension to drive the human story. The Superior Wakan Beings — Wakan Tanka, Wi, Skan, Inyan — embody order, structure, and cosmic law, but order without disruption is stagnation. Unk is the necessary turbulence. The Unktehi water spirits are depicted in Lakota art as great serpentine creatures with horns, often carved into catlinite pipes or painted on hides, and their conflict with the Wakinyan Thunderbirds is one of the foundational mythic tensions — sky against water, lightning against flood, the force that strikes down against the force that pulls under. Psychologically, Unk maps onto what depth psychology calls the shadow: the emotional powers that, if denied, grow monstrous, but if acknowledged and related to, become sources of vitality. The rivers and creeks around Mato Tipila — the Belle Fourche, the tributaries feeding the Missouri watershed — carry Unk's presence through the landscape, the water that carved the sedimentary layers away from the tower's igneous core over millions of years, patiently exposing what was hidden.

deities.name: Iktomi
deities.title: The Spider Trickster
deities.description: Iktomi, the Spider, is the great trickster of Lakota tradition — the cunning, shape-shifting being who once was Ksa, the spirit of wisdom, but who fell from grace through his own cleverness and was transformed into a spider, condemned to spin webs that are marvels of engineering but that exist only to trap others. He is the one who tricked Hanwi into sitting in Wi's seat, causing her banishment to the night sky. He appears in countless Lakota stories as a schemer whose plans almost always backfire: he tricks other animals, seduces, lies, cheats, and manipulates, but his schemes collapse because he cannot see past his own cleverness to its consequences. Ella Deloria's collections of Lakota oral narratives include Iktomi stories told to children specifically as moral instruction — not through heavy-handed lessons but through laughter. You laugh at Iktomi's failures, and in laughing you recognize the Iktomi in yourself: the part of you that thinks you're smarter than the situation, the part that spins elaborate justifications for selfish acts, the part that cannot stop talking long enough to listen. He is related to Coyote in other Plains traditions and to trickster figures worldwide — Hermes, Loki, Anansi, Eshu — the archetype that disrupts every system it enters. But the Lakota understanding of Iktomi contains a specific insight: wisdom and trickery share a root. Ksa was wise before he was Iktomi; intelligence without humility becomes manipulation. The dreamcatcher, which Iktomi is said to have taught the Lakota to weave, is his web repurposed — a trap that catches nightmares instead of prey, cleverness redirected toward protection. At Mato Tipila, Iktomi stories are part of the oral tradition associated with the site, the trickster's voice woven into the narrative landscape alongside the sacred accounts.

deities.name: Capa
deities.title: The Beaver Spirit
deities.description: Capa, the Beaver, is one of the spirit beings who represents industriousness, domestic skill, and the quiet transformation of landscapes through persistent, patient labor. In the Walker documents and in broader Lakota tradition, Capa is associated with the ability to reshape the world not through dramatic power but through sustained effort — the beaver who fells trees and dams rivers, creating ponds that become meadows that become ecosystems. This is not a minor theme. The Lakota observed that the beaver's work altered entire watersheds: upstream forests flooded, downstream flows changed, new wetlands emerged that attracted waterfowl, fish, and the plants that grew in saturated soil. One animal, through persistence, rebuilt the world around itself. Capa is invoked in contexts related to preparation, skill with tools, and the kind of labor that benefits the community rather than the individual — the beaver does not dam the river for personal glory but because that is what beavers do, and the result feeds the whole web of relations. In women's quillwork and beadwork societies, Capa's qualities of precision and patience were honored; the elaborate geometric designs on Lakota clothing and tipis required exactly the beaver's combination of skill and endurance. The streams and creeks around Mato Tipila — the Belle Fourche River system, the small tributaries running through the ponderosa pine forests at the tower's base — were historically beaver country, the animal's dams and lodges shaping the hydrology of the landscape. Capa is the reminder that not all sacred work is dramatic, that the quiet reshaping of conditions over time is itself a form of power.

deities.name: Iya
deities.title: The Storm Monster
deities.description: Iya is the great storm monster, the embodiment of destructive natural force — blizzards, tornadoes, the killing cold of northern Plains winters that could freeze a person in minutes and bury entire encampments in snow. In the Walker narratives, Iya is associated with Unk and with the forces that oppose the Thunderbird; where Wakinyan brings the storms that clear the air and renew the land, Iya brings the storms that destroy without purpose, the chaotic violence of weather beyond any being's control. He is depicted as enormous, insatiable, capable of swallowing whole camps, and his breath is the wind that drives whiteout blizzards across the Dakota prairies. The Lakota relationship to Iya is not simple demonization. The northern Great Plains are among the most climatically extreme inhabited landscapes on Earth — summer temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, winter temperatures below minus 40, blizzards that arrive in hours and last for days, tornadoes that touch down on open grassland visible for miles but unreachable by shelter. To live on the Plains is to live with Iya as a neighbor. The Lakota did not pretend this force could be appeased or controlled; they named it, acknowledged its power, and organized their lives around survival in its presence — the tipi designed to shed wind, the winter camps positioned in sheltered coulees, the dried meat and pemmican stored against the siege of weather. At Mato Tipila, Iya's presence is felt in the winter storms that scour the tower, coating its columns in ice, driving temperatures far below zero, turning the landscape into a white void where the monolith stands as the only vertical reference point. Iya is the honest acknowledgment that nature includes forces that do not care about you and cannot be negotiated with, and that survival depends on respect rather than mastery.
animals: none — Iya is beyond animal form
